title: 103_s639
content:
The title "Antidrug Assault Weapons Limitation Act of 1993" includes definitions for assault weapons. The "Antidrug Assault Weapons Limitation Act of 1993" defines assault weapons as specific firearms including Norinco, Mitchell, and Poly Technologies Avtomat Kalashnikovs, Action Arms Israeli Military Industries UZI and Galil, Beretta AR-70, Colt AR-15 and CAR-15, Fabrique Nationale FN/FAL, MAC 10 and MAC 11, Steyr AUG, INTRATEC TEC-9, Street Sweeper, and Striker 12. The term "form 4473" refers to the prescribed form by the Secretary in the Code of Regulations. The Secretary, in consultation with the Attorney General, may recommend to Congress the addition or deletion of firearms designated as assault weapons under section 921(29). SEC. 103. UNLAWFUL ACTS. 931. Additional assault weapons. Section 922 of title 18, United States Code, prohibits the transfer, import, transport, shipment, receipt, or possession of an assault weapon, with exceptions for government agencies and possession before the effective date of the subsection. It is also illegal to sell, ship, or deliver an assault weapon without the completion of form 4473. It is illegal to deliver an assault weapon without filling out form 4473. Purchasing or possessing an assault weapon also requires filling out form 4473. Both the buyer and seller must keep a record of the sale on form 4473 if the purchase is made from a non-licensed dealer. Owners of assault weapons must request a copy of form 4473 from a licensed dealer within 90 days of regulations being published by the Secretary. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for the request and delivery of form 4473 within 90 days of enactment. SEC. 104 amends penalties under Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, for firearm violations, including imprisonment for assault weapons. A new subsection imposes fines and imprisonment for knowingly violating section 922(t). SEC. 105 expands disability provisions in Section 922(g)(1). SEC. 106 mandates a study by the Attorney General. The Attorney General is required to conduct a study to investigate the impact of the Act and its amendments on violent and drug trafficking crimes over 18 months. A detailed report must be submitted to Congress within 30 months of the Act's enactment. The Act and its amendments will take effect 30 days after enactment and will be repealed after 3 years. TITLE II--INDISCRIMINATE USE OF WEAPONS TO FURTHER DRUG CONSPIRACIES

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE: This title may be cited as the "Drive-By Shooting Prevention Act of 1993".

SEC. 202. DRIVE-BY SHOOTING. The Drive-By Shooting Prevention Act of 1993, under Title II, introduces penalties for firing a weapon into a group of two or more persons in connection with a major drug offense, with the intent to intimidate, harass, injure, or maim. Offenders causing grave risk to human life face up to 25 years in prison or fines. If the firing results in a death, the offender may face harsher penalties. The penalties for killing someone in connection with a major drug offense are outlined in the law. If it is first-degree murder, the punishment can be death, life imprisonment, fines, or a combination. For other types of murder, fines, imprisonment, or both apply. A major drug offense includes a continuing criminal enterprise or conspiracy to distribute controlled substances. The text chunk outlines the penalties for major drug offenses under specific sections of the Controlled Substances Act and the Controlled Substances Import and Export Control Act. It also includes a technical amendment to the chapter analysis of title 18, United States Code. "Title III covers miscellaneous firearms offenses, including penalties for stealing and smuggling firearms." Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include new subsections (i) and (j) imposing penalties for stealing firearms involved in interstate commerce and for intending to engage in drug-related or violent activities. The amendment to Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, includes penalties for smuggling firearms into the country, with a maximum imprisonment of 10 years and fines. MANDATORY REVOCATION OF SUPERVISED RELEASE FOR POSSESSION OF A FIREARM. Section 3583 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include mandatory revocation of supervised release for possession of a firearm. If a defendant violates the condition of refraining from possessing a firearm during supervised release, the court must revoke the release term and may require the defendant to serve time in prison without credit for previous postrelease supervision.
